Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Ultrasound Guidance for Femoral Perineural Catheters

Trial_Design.evidence: patients undergoing knee arthroplasty were randomly assigned

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to one of three groups: 1) ultrasound alone (n=147); 2) ultrasound with electrical stimulation through the needle (n=152); or 3) ultrasound with electrical stimulation through both the needle and catheter (n=138)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed whether ultrasound guidance alone is noninferior to ultrasound with electrical stimulation for femoral perineural catheter placement

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were postoperative pain scores on a 0–10 Verbal Response Scale (VRS) and opioid consumption, assessed over 48 hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: ultrasound alone (n=147); 2) ultrasound with electrical stimulation through the needle (n=152); or 3) ultrasound with electrical stimulation through both the needle and catheter (n=138)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The stimulating needle group was noninferior to the stimulating catheter group in mean VRS pain score (difference −0.16, 95% CI −0.61 to 0.29, P<0.001) and opioid consumption (percent difference −5%, 95% CI −25% to 21%, P=0.002).
